importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the timing of China's announcement of new export controls on rare-earth metals.
The effective date for most of the new export restrictions, when foreign companies must obtain special approvals to export rare-earth products from China.

The expected date of Trump's visit to South Korea for the APEC summit, where he is expected to meet President Xi Jinping. This timing is crucial as it frames the strategic context of the new export controls.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between the announcement of the export controls and their implementation, during which the US and China are negotiating amid heightened tensions, giving China leverage ahead of a high-level summit.
The previous 90-day trade truce between the US and China, which has now been extended, signaling ongoing negotiations and the context in which China's new export controls are being introduced.

keyTakeAways: China has tightened export controls on 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals, including five newly added metals: holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium, and seven previously restricted ones: samarium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, lutetium, scandium, and yttrium.

The restrictions apply to both rare-earth metals and specialized technological equipment used to refine them, requiring foreign companies to obtain special approvals and explain the intended use of the products.
China cites national security concerns and the risk of sensitive military applications by foreign entities as the primary justification for these controls.

The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth metals and products, having imported $22.8 million worth of such goods in 2023, with 70% of its rare-earth imports originating from China between 2020 and 2023.

Rare-earth metals are critical for defense technologies such as F-35 fighter jets, submarines, missiles, radar systems, and AI semiconductors, making the controls strategically significant for both nations.

The move is seen as a strategic signaling effort by China to strengthen its leverage ahead of a high-level meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea.
China’s actions reflect its dominant role in global rare-earth production and processing (60% mining, 90% processing), allowing it to exert influence through supply chain control.
The US has faced prior restrictions on Chinese semiconductors, and now China’s actions may undermine US industrial and defense capabilities, especially as Indo-Pacific tensions rise.
Exemptions exist for exports related to emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, or disaster relief, ensuring humanitarian access is maintained.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has announced new and expanded export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five newly added types—holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium—plus seven previously restricted ones. These controls, effective from December 1, 2025, apply not only to the metals themselves but also to specialized refining equipment. The Chinese government justifies the move on national security grounds, citing foreign entities' use of Chinese rare-earth materials for military applications. The move occurs just weeks before a high-level meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea, suggesting a strategic effort to strengthen China’s leverage in ongoing trade negotiations. The US, the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, faces significant disruptions in its defense sector—including for F-35 jets, submarines, missiles, and AI technologies—while also affecting civilian technologies such as electric vehicles and smartphones. Analysts interpret the action as a signaling maneuver to assert China’s dominance in the global rare-earth supply chain. Exemptions exist for emergency medical, public health, and disaster relief purposes, ensuring humanitarian access. This development underscores the deep interdependence and strategic tension between the US and China in critical technological and supply chains.
title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
